a-sample-case.Question: The source of law that is foundational in the US legal system is
“Law is the command of a sovereign” represents what school of legal thought?
Which of the following kinds of law are most often found in state law rather than federal law?

Answers.Text: in the exercise of human reason

a-sample-case.Question: Wolfe is a state court judge in California. In the case of Riddick v. Clouse, which involves a contract dispute, Wolfe must follow precedent. She establishes a logical relationship between the Riddick case and a case decided by the California Supreme Court, Zhu v. Patel Enterprises, Inc. She compares the facts of Riddick to the facts in Zhu and to the extent the facts are similar, applies the same rule to reach her decision. This is

Moore is a state court judge in Colorado. In the case of Cassidy v. Seawell, also a contract dispute, there is no Colorado Supreme Court or court of appeals decision that sets forth a rule that could be applied. However, the California case of Zhu v. Patel Enterprises, Inc. is “very close” on the facts and sets forth a rule of law that could be applied to the Cassidy case. What process must Moore follow in considering whether to use the Zhu case as precedent?

Answers.Text: Moore is free to decide the case any way he wants, but he may not look at decisions and reasons in similar cases from other states.
Moore must wait for the Colorado legislature and the governor to pass a law that addresses the issues raised in the Cassidy case.
Moore must follow the California case if that is the best precedent.
Moore may follow the California case if he believes that it offers the best reasoning for a similar case.

cases-4.Question: Under what clause of the Constitution must each state court respect the final judgments of courts in other states?
Which of the following types of cases would typically be dealt with by state courts?

Answers.Text: Cases that have a clear federal connection

cases-4.Question: What can a party do if they believe a discovery request is for privileged material or made to harass?

Answers.Text: Apply to the court for a protective order

cases-4.Question: According to Rule 50(b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, how many days after the entry of judgment can a party who has moved for a directed verdict move to have the verdict and any judgment entered thereon set aside?

What requirement is satisfied if the defendant has “purposefully directed” his activities at residents of the forum, and the litigation results from alleged injuries that “arise out of or relate to” those activities?
What does the appellate court review to try to find a legal error on a specific request of one or both of the parties?
Under what circumstances might a single lawsuit be a more efficient way of determining liability and deciding financial responsibility than many individual lawsuits?

Answers.Text: When the potential plaintiffs were all injured in the same way and their injuries were identical
When the potential plaintiffs have different injuries but were injured in the same accident
hen the potential plaintiffs have the same injuries but were injured in different accidents
When the potential plaintiffs have different injuries and were injured in different accidents

cases-5.Question: Harvey filed a suit against the state of Colorado, claiming that a Colorado state law violates the commerce clause. The court will agree if the statute

Answers.Text: places an undue burden on interstate commerce
promotes the public health, safety, morals, or general welfare of Colorado
regulates economic activities within the state’s borders

cases-5.Question: The state legislature in Maine enacts a law that directly conflicts with a federal law. Mapco Industries, located in Portland, Maine, cannot comply with both the state and the federal law.

Answers.Text: Because of federalism, the state law will have priority, as long as Maine is using its police powers.
Because there’s a conflict, both laws are invalid; the state and the federal government will have to work out a compromise of some sort.
The federal law preempts the state law.

cases-5.Question: Hannah, who lives in Ada, is the owner of Superior Enterprises, Inc. She believes that certain actions in the state of Ohio infringe on her federal constitutional rights, especially those found in the Bill of Rights. Most of these rights apply to the states under

Answers.Text: the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment

cases-5.Question: Minnesota enacts a statute that bans all advertising that is in “bad taste,” “vulgar,” or “indecent.” In Michigan, Aaron Calloway and his brother, Clarence “Cab” Calloway, create unique beer that they decide to call Old Fart Ale. In their marketing, the brothers have a label in which an older man in a dirty T-shirt is sitting in easy chair, looking disheveled and having a three-day growth of stubble on his chin. It appears that the man is in the process of belching. He is also holding a can of Old Fart Ale. The Minnesota liquor commission orders all Minnesota restaurants, bars, and grocery stores to remove Old Fart Ale from their shelves. The state statute and the commission’s order are likely to be held by a court to be

Answers.Text: a violation of the Tenth Amendment
a violation of the First Amendment
a violation of the Calloways’ right to equal protection of the laws
a violation of the commerce clause, since only the federal laws can prevent an article of commerce from entering into Minnesota’s market

cases-5.Question: Raunch Unlimited, a Virginia partnership, sells smut whenever and wherever it can. Some of its material is “obscene” (meeting the Supreme Court’s definition under Miller v. California) and includes child pornography. North Carolina has a statute that criminalizes obscenity. What are possible results if a store in Raleigh, North Carolina, carries Raunch merchandise?

Answers.Text: The partners could be arrested in North Carolina and may well be convicted.
The materials in Raleigh may be the basis for a criminal conviction.
The materials are protected under the First Amendment’s right of free speech.
The materials are protected under state law.

cases-1.Question: Catarina falsely accuses Jeff of stealing from their employer. The statement is defamatory only if

Answers.Text: Nick suffers severe emotional distress as a result
the statement is the actual and proximate cause of his distress
the statement is widely circulated in the local media and on Twitter

cases-1.Question: Garrett files a suit against Colossal Media Corporation for defamation. Colossal has said that Garrett is a “sleazy, corrupt public official” (and provided some evidence to back the claim). To win his case, Garrett will have to show that Colossal acted with

Big Burger begins a rumor, using social media, that the meat in Burger World is partly composed of ground-up worms. The rumor is not true, as Big Burger well knows. Its intent is to get some customers to shift loyalty from Burger World to Big Burger. Burger World’s best cause of action would be

Wilfred Phelps, age 65, is driving his Nissan Altima down Main Street when he suffers the first seizure of his life. He loses control of his vehicle and runs into three people on the sidewalk. Which statement is true?

Answers.Text: He is liable for an intentional tort.
He is liable for a negligent tort.
He is not liable for a negligent tort.
He is liable under strict liability, because driving a car is abnormally dangerous.

cases-1.Question: Jonathan carelessly bumps into Amanda, knocking her to the ground. He has committed the tort of negligence

Answers.Text: only if Amanda is not injured
whether or not Amanda is injured
is one in which the terms are spelled out
is one inferred from the actions of the parties
is imposed by law to avoid an unjust result
may be avoided by one party

cases.Question: The Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods is

Answers.Text: an annual meeting of international commercial purchasing agents.
contract law used in overseas US federal territories
a customary format or template for drafting contracts
a kind of treaty setting out international contract law, to which the United States is a party
the organization that develops uniform international law
void, not a contract at all
one that a court will not enforce for either side because of a rule of law
unenforceable by one party but enforceable by the other
one that has been performed by one party but not the other

cases.Question: Betty Baker found a bicycle apparently abandoned near her house. She took it home and spent $150 repairing and painting it, after which Carl appeared and proved his ownership of it. Under what theory is Betty able to get reimbursed for her expenditures?

Answers.Text: none: she will not get reimbursed

cases.Question: Alice discusses with her neighbor Bob her plan to hire Woodsman to cut three trees on her side of their property line, mentioning that she can get a good deal because Woodsman is now between jobs. Bob says, “Oh, don’t do that. My brother is going to cut some trees on my side, and he can do yours too for free.” Alice agrees. But Bob’s brother is preoccupied and never does the job. Three weeks later Alice discovers Woodsman’s rates have risen prohibitively. Under what theory does Alice have a cause of action against Bob?

Answers.Text: none: she has no cause of action against Bob

cases-6.Question: In interpreting agreements for the purpose of establishing whether a valid contract exists, courts generally apply

Answers.Text: either a subjective or an objective standard
must specify time, place, and manner of acceptance
must be accepted immediately to be valid
can only be accepted by the same means it was made
can be revoked if the offeror changes his or her mind
can lapse after a reasonable period of time

cases-6.Question: An acceptance is generally considered effective

Answers.Text: when a letter is received by the offeror
only when the acceptance is transmitted in writing
only tort theories are typically asserted
both tort and contract theories are typically asserted
strict liability is asserted only when negligence is not asserted
breach of warranty is not asserted along with strict liability
is created by an express warranty
is impossible for a seller to disclaim
can be disclaimed by a seller only if the disclaimer is in writing

cases-2.Question: A possible defense to breach of warranty is
Under the strict liability rule in Restatement, Section 402A, the seller is liable for all injuries resulting from a product

Answers.Text: even though all possible care has been exercised
regardless of the lack of a contract with the user
in both of the above situations
in none of the above situations

cases-2.Question: An individual selling her car could be liable

Answers.Text: for breaching the implied warranty of merchantability
for breaching the implied warranty of fitness
